title: 109_hr2936
content: The "Second Opinion Coverage Act of 2005" is also known as the "Second Opinion Coverage Act." It amends the Public Health Service Act to include coverage of second opinions in group health plans. The "Second Opinion Coverage Act of 2005" requires group health plans to provide or authorize a second opinion by a qualified healthcare professional when requested by a participant, beneficiary, or enrollee questioning the reasonableness or necessity of recommended surgical procedures. The "Second Opinion Coverage Act of 2005" mandates group health plans to offer a second opinion for surgical procedures in specific situations like life-threatening conditions, unclear diagnoses, or ineffective treatment plans. The "Second Opinion Coverage Act of 2005" requires group health plans to provide a second opinion if the current treatment plan is not improving the medical condition within a reasonable time, or if the patient has serious concerns about the diagnosis or plan of care. The "Second Opinion Coverage Act of 2005" mandates that group health plans must offer a second opinion from an appropriately qualified health care professional if the current treatment is ineffective or if there are concerns about the diagnosis or care plan. The opinion must be provided promptly upon request. The Second Opinion Coverage Act of 2005 requires timely provision of a second opinion when there is a serious threat to health, with a deadline of 72 hours after the request is received by the plan or issuer. Each plan or issuer must provide timelines for responding to second opinion requests within 90 days of enactment, and update them within 30 days. The public can request these timelines. If a request for a second opinion is approved, the participant is only responsible for the costs. If a participant requests a second opinion from their primary care physician, it must be provided by a qualified healthcare professional of their choice within the same physician organization. For second opinions from specialists, the participant can choose any provider for the opinion. If a participant requests a second opinion from their primary care physician, it must be provided by a qualified healthcare professional of their choice within the same physician organization. For second opinions from specialists, the participant can choose any provider for the opinion, and the plan or issuer will cover the cost or negotiate fee arrangements. If there is no participating provider within the network, the enrollee is responsible for seeking additional medical opinions. If a participant cannot find a participating provider within the network, the plan or issuer will authorize a second opinion from a qualified health professional outside the network. The plan will consider the participant's ability to travel to the provider but is not responsible for travel costs. The second opinion health professional must provide consultation reports. The plan or issuer will authorize a second opinion from a qualified health professional outside the network if a participant cannot find a participating provider. The second opinion health professional must provide consultation reports, including any recommended procedures or tests. If the plan denies a request for a second opinion, the participant will be notified in writing. The plan must notify the participant of denial reasons and their right to file a grievance. Services must be obtained from participating providers unless authorized otherwise. Referrals may be limited to the plan's network of providers. The plan may limit referrals to its network of providers if a participating plan provider meets specified standards. Health care service plan contracts exempt from this section must provide access to second opinions. Group health plans must comply with notice requirements under ERISA. The Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 is amended to include new requirements for health care service plan contracts and group health plans under ERISA. "SEC. 714. COVERAGE OF SECOND OPINIONS." The provisions of section 2707 apply to group health plans and insurance coverage. The requirement is considered a material modification for notice under the plan. Section 104(b)(1) requires providing notice of modifications within 60 days of the first plan year. Sections 731(c) and 732(a) of the Act are amended to include additional sections. The table of contents is updated to reflect the changes. Coverage of second opinions is added to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 under section 9813. Coverage of second opinions is included in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 under section 9813, with requirements similar to those in the Public Health Service Act. The provisions of section 2707 apply to health insurance coverage in the individual market, with notice requirements similar to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974. Effective Dates: The amendments apply to group health plans for plan years starting on or after January 1, 2006, and to individual health insurance coverage offered, sold, issued, renewed, or operated. The amendments apply to group health plans for plan years starting on or after January 1, 2006, and to individual health insurance coverage in the individual market. There is an exception for group health plans maintained under collective bargaining agreements ratified before the enactment of the Act. The amendments apply to group health plans starting on or after January 1, 2006. Plan amendments made to conform to new requirements do not terminate collective bargaining agreements. Secretaries of Labor, Treasury, and Health and Human Services coordinate administration. Services will ensure that regulations, rulings, and interpretations issued by the Secretaries are administered consistently and that enforcement policies are coordinated to avoid duplication of efforts and prioritize enforcement.
